who wants to leave that please hi there I'm sandal I work on the open pollinated
project I will also mention that I have Tim Hinrich from steerer and Tristan's
Weddell from Google here as well and so they can help answer questions towards the end so going to slide 24 what we
want to talk about today is the open policy agent so you want to give everybody an overview of the project talk a little bit about how we've gotten
to where we are today what's happening inside the community and then kind of talk about where we hoped ahead with the
project in the future so going to slide 25 I just want to give a little bit of a
background on how we look at policy to make sure everybody's on the same page and so when I'm talking about policy
what I'm talking about are you know rules or the rules that sort of govern how systems are expected to behave and
the interesting thing about these rules these policies is that they're vital to every single organization because they
codify important requirements from things like cost and performance and security and so on but the challenges
that these policies are often very difficult to enforce because the organization's have to apply them across the stack in different environments on
different platforms and from languages and they're often very organization specific and they're hard to predict
because they sort of sort of evolve organically inside of organizations and they tend to change a lot over time and
so when it comes to actually enforcing these policies a lot of the time people fall back to things like tribal knowledge they kind of just hope that the system
and people are doing the right things as they don't get very strong guarantees when they're trying to enforce policy on
the other hand if they try to sort of hard-code the policy decisions they end up sorry
so they end up with policy decisions that are sort of difficult to understand and expensive to change because they end
up so tightly coupled with the rest of the application business logic now none of this is really necessarily new there
are existing policy solutions in the space but what you find when you dig into them is that a lot of time they lack sort of like fundamental
expressiveness around the things you can say so for example they don't support the kind of logic you want they don't give you access to context and data that
you need to make decisions or they don't let you actually produce the kinds of decisions you need to produce or
moreover you can't compose policies and so on so going to slide 26 the open
policy agent is an open source general-purpose policy engine and the goal of the project is to solve a lot of
these problems so what we mean by general purpose is that you can take open and you can apply it at any layer
of the stack in any system and so whether you're talking about you know policy enforcement and micro services or
you know cluster orchestrators or CIC D pipelines OPA provides like a reusable building block that you can use to
enforce policy now at the core of OPA is a high-level declarative policy language
called Rago and what that language gives you is a high-level way to define rules to question that answer questions like
you know can a service perform some operation on some resource or you know what clusters should a work load be
placed on or what labels have to be set on an object when it's created and so on and so one of the powerful features of
the language is it lets you define policy decisions that are non boolean and so in Rago it's no problem to
express you know a set of clusters that a workload should be placed on or a collection of key value pairs that need to be applied to an object but it's
created now when you integrate with OPA you can you have two sort of two options
you can either use it as a library or a daemon but in either case it works the same way so what you do is you give OPA
a set of policies and a set of data and then you offload your policy decisions to it and so the way this works is that
as a service when you need to make a policy decision what you do is you execute a query against OPA and oh but takes the policy and data in the query
and it can it's an answer or policy decision and it sends that decision back to your service and in doing so you've basically
decoupled the policy decision from your service now in addition to the core sort
of evaluation engine that you get with OPA we also give you a bunch of tooling to help you like develop and test and
debug your policies Oba itself is actually written in go now and it's
designed to be extremely lightweight so like I said you can take it and you can embed it in other go applications but
you can also run it as a sidecar or a host level agent and it stores all of the policies and data that knows about
in memory and it has zero sort of run time or deployment time dependencies by itself ok so moving the select 27 so we
took this project and we released it in July 2016 that was the initial release and the
goal of the time was basically to create a sort of general-purpose policy engine that allowed you to make policy
decisions over arbitrary JSON data and the reason for that which is still true
today is that a lot of the time when you're making these policy decisions in modern systems you're trying to reason about information or reason or
information that's represented as complex deeply nested document oriented data and so that's sort of when we
execute it on at a time and we created this this new project OPA in the open we could the new language and then the
necessary runtime to take it and integrate it with existing systems in the space and so then following that we
sort of moved into a phase where we focused more on applying open to different problems in space and so the
goal there was really to solve real problems that people have in the field and in the process you know we built up a little community around OPA and we
also learned a bunch of requirements for Oba and earth Hill Climb done the implementation and so we took it and we applied it to different domains and
different projects and saw a lot of success now at this point we're still sort of looking for new use cases and
new domains to apply open but we're also really focused on hardening the implementation and sort of applying or
building out a more advanced feature set so in terms of community moving onto
slide 28 like I said we started open in early 2016 and then and then the goal
has always would have been to have this sort of reusable building block that would complement other projects in the ecosystem and so then
earlier this year we got in touch with Google and Tristan a little tip we were linking Tristan and what we realized was
a lot of us were working on similar use cases and we were actually using a similar approach and what we were all
recognized was that it would be valuable if there was an open a single open you
know vendor-neutral solution within the industry that people to use and that we'd all be better off that was the case
and so since about May of this year Google has been actively working with us
on the project at this point we have people across both companies that are actually contributing now in terms of
adoption we've seen a lot of growth this year which is really exciting so for example Netflix has started using OPA in
the core of their authorization system and so what OPA provides to Netflix is this high performance engine that they
can offload authorization decisions to so regardless of whether they're dealing with you know different protocols or
resource types or execution environments opens there to answer policy questions that they have at runtime and so in
Netflix's onwards OPA helps them solve like a fundamental security problem and also get there
faster which is really cool and so today at netflix opens being used across
multiple teams and solving authorization in HTTP API is G RPC API is Kafka and
we're really excited to so we're really happy to be helping with that and we're looking forward to use cases going
forward Medallia is another company that's using OPA and so Medallia what
they used up before is to make authorization decisions over changes that terraform wants to make in order to
reduce risk and so for example different people in the company might have different risk budgets associated with
the changes they can make and so that helps them make sure that their infrastructure is stable and reliable in
